intro: Jamesbrittenia grandiflora, commonly known as the large-flowered Jamesbrittenia, is a striking member of the Malvaceae family, characterized by its showy, trumpet-shaped flowers. Native to the eastern United States, it thrives in moist, well-drained soils and partial to full sunlight. The plant features palmate leaves with five to seven lobes, adding to its ornamental appeal. Its flowers, which range from pink to red, bloom in late spring to early summer, attracting pollinators like bees and butterflies. Due to its beauty and ecological value, it is often cultivated in gardens and conservation areas.
